I bought this for my boyfriend who is normally a PC gamer (and who chose the 5-star rating for this review), but he wanted to play a few certain switch games. He really loves it and to my surprise wishes he had some of his PC games on the Switch Lite instead. He likes the d-pad on the right which the normal switch doesn‚Äôt have since the joycons all need to be the same. The one con to this compared to the normal switch is that if it‚Äôs low on battery and he wants to play, he needs to sit by the wall to charge it. No docking option. Games with a lot of text are especially nice for him on this because he has a hard time reading the text on the TV, but not when playing handheld. Of course you could achieve this with a regular switch, but at a higher price point. So in conclusion, if you have a hard time with reading on the TV and would like to play handheld all of the time, this is a great alternative to the normal switch. On the other hand, if you like playing on the TV or if your eyes have a hard time looking at small, close up screens for long periods of time like mine, the normal switch is worth the cost.

The switch lite is a great product, but the majority of the switch lites out right now has a slight joycon drift. The left stick on mine has a slight drift when I push it to the right. Its mildly annoying, but not enough that I'd send my system for repair.  Has enough battery life to play on the go and the internal memory is enough to hold multiple downloaded games before having to buy an sd card. Overall, its a great product.

Surprisingly good graphics for a handheld version of the Switch. The screen is somewhat smaller than the Switch cnosole's one, but the games still look great. It's really nice to have a handheld version of the console with very little sacrifices. The only minor complaint I have with the Switch Lite is that the battery life is somewhat lacking. I know the graphics are really good for a handheld, but I wish the battery lasted for several or more hours longer than it does. I mean, you still get around 3-4 hours on average per charge, but would have liked it if the battery lasted for like around 6-8 hours. Oh well, you sacrifice battery life for really good graphics, so it can't be helped. Other than that, I have no complains about the Switch Lite. It is very easy to hold in your hands and doesn't feel awkward. The buttons, directional pad, and analog stick placements are really good. The speakers are not the best, but gets loud enough and sounds good. I did notice the back gets sort of hot while charging and playing games at the same time, but not too hot. This is a nice handheld game system to add to your collection, especially if you like JRPGs (Japanese-style role playing games). As of now, there is a pretty good selection of these game you can purchase and play.

She was so surprised and her father and I couldn't have been happier.

Not to mention the game options and variety. I‚Äôve played over 70 hours of Breath of the Wild, and loved it. The other indie games available are also great additions. Overall, it‚Äôs a great system. On paper this is such a slick device, and combined with great Nintendo titles this was something I was excited for. BUT this system just isn't there yet. Right now I'm dealing with input lag that goes beyond controller or title specific issues. Right from the get go, setting it up (while in portable mode) felt odd. The touch screen and the attached joy-cons felt a bit slow. The input lag was the same speed as my PS4 with my TVs game mode OFF. Not a huge deal for many who will play most casual games, but annoying enough for me that titles like Cuphead and Enter the Gungeon are hindered. I do wonder if the newer portable only version doesn't have these issues, but I'm mainly interested in this as a home console. And it's online component? They still haven't caught up with Xbox Live from the 360 generation. Not a huge problem with Discord around, but still. Lot's of pluses for this system for sure, but this is mainly a message to people to try out the system first and decide for yourself if the input lag is bad enough to ruin your experience. A lot of people are very satisfied and don't even notice. I can see this not being a problem in games like Pokemon, or Mario + Rabbids Kingdom Battle. I've been playing "The Touryst", charming, relaxing, and a nice change of pace from what I usually play.

I bought this system for myself as a birthday present, and I have enjoyed using it!  The controllers took a bit getting used to detaching on and off properly.  I think the main thing is to be careful about what games you buy if the device will be worth it to you in the end, or if you are excited about upcoming games.  I waited to purchase the Switch until I knew there were about ten games I wanted to play and added about three of them into the in initial cost as well.  I‚Äôm pretty picky about my games because I am a casual gamer. Zelda breath of the wild‚Äîwhich I borrowed from my brother later‚Äî is more intensive than anything I have played in YEARS. Games are expensive in physical format, although that is my preference.  There are some cheaper games on the online store.  So far my favorite local game shop does not have any used copies of Switch games although they have everything else.  Maybe some day. I might buy a screen protector for it in the future but have not as of yet.  If your Switch is to see heavy use by an entire family or if as an owner you plan to travel with it I‚Äôd recommend one but that is not the case for me. I did have a problem within a month of ordering the machine where the fan started whirring LOUDLY.  At first only when it was plugged in to charge then all the time when it was at rest, then at last even while playing a game.  I called Nintendo customer service and had it repaired (although I had to send it back three times with the same issue to a radioshack in Syracuse NY.  Last time I sent it in they just replaced the system.) If I have a problem in the future I will request replacement rather than repair, especially if it‚Äôs going back to New York.  Just not happening.  At least customer service was good, but I was becoming a bit disgruntled toward the end there with their techs!  For my troubles customer service gave me a new set of controllers automatically and then later, three months free on the eshop.  Oh, and the second and third shipments were two day free.

I really like the idea of having a smaller, more portable version of the switch. This model is great for roadtrips, killing time at the DMV, or plainly just for playing all of those titles that are being remade for nostalgia purposes. The only thing i really dislike is the button layout. Having the joystick directly under the numerical buttons normally used for strategic moves in shooters  makes games like that a little harder if you dont have a pro controller. Overall id give this system a 9/10 with its only draw back being the button layout

I love having the switch lite! It feels so much more comfortable in your hands than the normal N-Switch and I've been playing much more lite switch games on the go because I'm a person, who's not home much and I love many of my switch games but I don't have much time to play them at home but with the switch lite, I can easily take it on the road with me and try to actually play them through for all the games I have for the system, for many months now and actually try to complete them and not let them go to waste. The lite is a great buy for anyone who really wants to play switch games on the go and it is also, at a better price point for those who aren't willing to shell out the extra $100-$150 more for the standard system but still want to be able to enjoy all of the great games that it does offer. It's definitely worth it, at least to me it is, I highly recommend it for people who travel on buses or trains to have something to entertain them on their way to work or anywhere else!

I'm mainly going to list off the pros for this unit, something I like that they did on this generation compared to the other consoles by Nintendo and some gripes. Portability obviously with its docking capabilities - very good move.  The way the Switch locates itself within the dock is a cool party trick.  I like not having to have a rucksack full of gear just to bring my system with. The Joy-Con controllers are passable and you can actually play 2P games with each one.  I do wish they offered a Pro-controller bundled version. The setup of the system is easy, you don't have to fill out another mortgage worth of EULAs to play. For pennies you get a slew of NES and SNES games through Nintendo Online. Mario Maker 2 is pretty fun and I wished more games had BYO levels like it (cue the wave of gamers that will correct me on 20+ games that have their own world-building options. I'm 43 and don't have time for games like I did in my teens.  Let me dip my filthy casual toe back in the game pool now that my kids are grown.)

This review is targeted at newcomers so for veterans of Nintendo products, not much new information here! As for everyone else looking at this gaming system wondering if its right for them, I'll do my best to explain what this model in particular brings to the table. In my particular case a: "Nintendo Switch with Gray Joy‚ÄëCon - HAC-001(-01)" Introduction to the system/What is a Nintendo Switch?: The Nintendo Switch is a "hybrid system". Lets break it down to its core do understand what people mean by "hybrid system", lets start with what is basically a gaming tablet with a plastic screen and a multi-touch-touchscreen. This is the "Switch itself" so to speak. For a "console", it is EXTREMELY thin in comparison to a PS4 or Xbox One for example. This also means it takes significantly less energy to run. The internal cooling fan is also significantly quieter than either of the prior two other consoles mentioned. That multi-touch-touchscreen allows for certain mobile games like Muse Dash, VOEZ, Deemo, and many others to be ported to the Switch without compromising their touch screen gimmicks from their mobile phone counterparts. Despite this, many of them do have support for button controls. Many Switch games gives you options on how you want to play and this is a running theme with the Switch. Now for the controllers which are "hybrid controllers" in a way. For those of you who used the Nintendo Wii, these "Joy Cons" share and improved upon the motion controls from the Wii days, except in addition to the motion controls, Nintendo also made the actual button layout resemble a regular controller like the button layout found on a Xbox One controller for example. Not that weird button layout on the Wii for example. This means both the Wii crowd can assimilate into this new generation of Nintendo, along side the core gamers who would prefer a more "traditional" controller button set up. Normally a player would use both Joy Cons together as a pair, whether that be attached to the Switch Tablet itself to be played on the go like a 3DS (be it much longer than a 3DS), at home and connected to a plastic grip that gives you those controller "thighs" to make it easier to hold and to make it feel more like a more traditional controller even more. You can even use the Joy Cons without them being attached to anything like the Wiimote and Numchuck, but without that annoying wire in between your controllers. This "detached" controller style option with the Joy Cons allows you to play in positions otherwise impossible with a more "static" controller. For example, you can play with one arm behind your head while the other arm is resting on your stomach as you play from your bed or couch. These Joy Cons also have two buttons on the plastic rails that connect them to the Switch Tablet piece. These buttons are functional and you can actually use just a single Joy Con per player in certain supported games. Key word "supported games". This is where the main issue with the Nintendo Switch lies, Nintendo laid the foundation for developers to have the best tools at their deposal but not all of them use them. Some developers have games that cost less overall on the Switch than their original releases on other systems, or from mobile with mobile's atrocious micro-transactions , meanwhile there's other developers that neither have the full game on the physical game cartridges while having the audacity to be more expensive on the Switch. But again, its ALL developer based. Research the game developers in question to see if you're getting the best value for buying their ports (or original) releases on the Nintendo Switch. Oh right, this gaming system uses cartridges. Don't worry, they're not those huge ones from the Nintendo 64 days! They're more Nintendo 3DS sized if anything. If the developer you choose did it properly, a entire game can fit on these cartridges. This means you can play those properly done physical releases immediately without any additional downloads. But again, developer based. Some of them DO only "partially" have the game on the Switch Cartridge(s). Do your research. Now to talk about the Dock that connects the Switch Tablet to a TV. If you open up the back side of the Dock, there should be two slits near the bottom of the Dock. The Switch Tablet has two air vents that when "docked" should be right up against those vents. Please try not to block off those vents so the Switch Tablet as a easier time cooling itself off while you (and others) play in "TV Mode". The Switch Tablet also has a air-vent on the top. So keep that area of the Switch Tablet clear as well. This particular model of the Nintendo Switch, model number "HAC-001(-01)", is different from day one Nintendo Switch systems in the sense that Switches with the model number "HAC-001(-01)" have better battery life. For example, day one Switches would run really graphically/resource intensive games for about 2 hours 30 minutes (or 2.5 hours) minimum. Whereas this new "HAC-001(-01)" numbered Switch(es) can run those games for up to 4.5 hours minimum in "handheld mode". The way these "new Switches" accomplish this is by having a more efficient component in the inside of the Tablet piece. This also means these new Switches are more energy efficient and less prone to overheating than the day one models. So this is even helpful for people who would use this gaming system for TV use. If you don't have a Switch yet, I recommend this model for its versatility. You never know when you'll change your mind on "how" you want to play. I used to use it mostly in TV mode but eventually started using it more and more while outside in general. For example, on the bus, while waiting for something to start whether it be a class, jury duty, meeting, you name it. The Nintendo Switch will make that wait all the less painful. Waiting to be called or dismissed for jury duty especially. Oh, I almost forgot! You CAN use power banks with the Nintendo Switch! The minimum power requirements for a power bank to work with a Nintendo Switch is 5 Volts, and 2.4 Amps. The cable you use to plug the Switch Tablet with a power bank can be found bundled with the Nintendo Switch Pro Controller, or the Nintendo Switch Charging Grip. Both of those products come with the USB cable required to use a Nintendo Switch with a power bank. So even if you manage to drain this new Switch's battery life on a long trip, bring a battery bank and you can extend its battery life even further. But again, this mostly won't be needed unless you're on a air ride for over 7 hours or so. Anything less than that, if you're smart about it, you can get away with just the Switch's battery life. Speaking of battery life, the Joy Cons each have a estimated battery life of 20 hours each. Let me repeat that, 20 hours. That brings its competition's controllers to shame! So if you keep your Joy Cons charged overnight (they charge when connected to the Switch Tablet while the Tablet is charging in either the Dock or via battery bank), they ain't going to die unless you deliberately go out of your way not to charge them at least once a week. When their batteries are completely dead, both the Switch Tablet and one pair of Joy Cons takes about 3 hours to fully charge everything. So if you're able to, put the Switch Tablet with the pair of Joy Cons connected to it, and leave the three of them in the Dock overnight to keep everything nice and charged for tomorrows challenges. Get creative, once you get used to the options the Nintendo Switch offers, going to anything else, you'll realize that you'd taken for granted with the Nintendo Switch! In my particular case, using the two Joy Cons in each hand unconnected. I can't do that with a keyboard and mouse! So get your Joy Cons, get them in a position that works for you, get cozy on your couch, bed, etc. and have some fun with your game(s) of choice! Just keep in mind it is a GAMING SYSTEM FIRST, and the "entertainment media center" SECOND. So as of January 15th, 2020 don't expect things like Netflix to be on this machine. If you treat it as a DEDICATED gaming system, you're in for one hell of a ride! Just don't forget your screen protector since the Switch Tablet's screen is made of plastic! If you don't want to go through all of them, get this one: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XDWBPMZ/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 It should serve most peoples' needs. Its durable, cheap, anti-glare, self heals from minor scratches, etc. Its the most value for the price I've found from searching through all of what Amazon has as far as Switch Tablet screen protectors go. As far as the "system itself" goes, this is pretty much all of the information that you'd need. Everything else is developer centered, game wise. Do your research, and think very carefully which developers will give you the best bang for your buck!

I knew people who owned the Switch were seemingly all very happy with it, and I planned on getting one at some point. When Pokemon moved to the Switch, "some point" became "right now". Nintendo likes to make their consoles unique. The DS Lite had two screens, a touch screen, and a microphone that were all used to make the experience unique. The 3DS, The Wii, and Wii U also had their own interesting elements. At times, it just felt gimmicky. The Switch on the other hand, doesn't feel that way at all. It's the gaming equivalent of a laptop with a docking station. You can have the TV experience like any other console, which is also great for party games. Then you can take it with you. This is basically THE go to gaming device for plane rides. The joycons are also genius. It is just incredibly versatile. I'm pleased that it has USB C. The Dock is easy to connect to as it literally just drops in place. I do think it could use more apps. it pretty much only has Hulu and YouTube at the time of this review, if I'm remembering correctly. I am a bit of a geek so I have plenty of other devices to watch on, but if it wants to compete with some of the other devices, it would be nice to have the option of watching Netflix, for example. I remember when the Wii first came out, and you'd go play the sports games with whoever had one. The novelty wore off before long. The Switch however, is here to stay. Brilliant device

This is, strangely enough, the first portable system I have ever bought in my 30+ years of gaming. I‚Äôve actually bought 2 Switches so far. The first one was a Christmas present for my son who I was trying to ease into video games. He loves it. After him having it for a year and me occasionally playing it to help him through areas where my greater experience with games could help get through certain areas, I was tempted to get one for myself to play when I had long periods of downtime at work. When Witcher 3 came out for the switch, I bought another one for me and have been playing it a few times per week since. My experience with the console is pretty much strictly in the handheld mode. I bought a Satisfye grip and case for my switch which allows me to hold the system more comfortably than I would without it. Holding the standard system and playing for more that 20 minutes or so causes my hands to cramp. The small joycons are just too small for adult male hands to use for long without some discomfort. I‚Äôm fine with that since the small size makes the system easier for kids, like my son, to use. A regular controller can be a bit bulky for a grade school age kid to use well. With the case and grip, this system is perfect for me to throw into my vehicle at work and forget about it until things slow down when I‚Äôm waiting for a call. Then I can break it out and pass the time in style. All in all, I have no complaints about the system, my son loves it and uses it constantly. I like it for its portable nature and surprising computing power. It is the first portable system I‚Äôve experienced that didn‚Äôt feel like a downgrade or gimmick. The Switch instead feels like a true portable version of a larger console like PS4 or XB1. I still play on my PS4 far more than I do the Switch, but I can‚Äôt take that system to work and play in the office or car. If you have young kids, or a desire to game on the go with something better than your phone, then it‚Äôs hard to go wrong with the switch.

Our household doesn‚Äôt buy the latest, greatest gaming systems but it was time to upgrade our original Wii for another family friendly system. The reviews were pretty glowing for the Switch and I can say they‚Äôre warranted. Just make sure you buy the newer generation (this product) so you have better battery life and less decline over the life of the product. I love how Nintendo the Parental Controls essentially live within an app on the parent‚Äôs phone. A motivated kid can hack just about anything so keeping these settings non-local is a brilliant little safeguard. My kids have to ask me for ‚Äúmore time‚Äù when they‚Äôve hit a daily limit (which is customizable for the day of the week). It‚Äôs very much like a simpler, more reliable version of Apple‚Äôs Screen Time feature on iPhones. Of course, you can also unlock more time on the switch itself using a pin code. It‚Äôs also worth mentioning that Nintendo did a great job with the ‚Äúuser assisted driving‚Äù feature on Mario Kart that helps young kids and inexperienced gamers be competitive. It really is nice to bring my youngest daughter into the joy of Mario Karting.

The only time I‚Äôve used a Switch has been playing on one that my friends own. Just these experiences has really intrigued me into getting my very own Switch. I love playing video games and I own an Xbox and PS4, so I figure at some point it was time to complete the trifecta. While I‚Äôm more of an Xbox person, I will say I am very impressed by the Switch. It is a very simple console, but genius in of itself. I‚Äôve had some Nintendo gaming devices here and there. A SNES back in the day, but mostly their portable ones from the Gameboy to the Advanced to the DS and 3DS. The Switch combines that of a home console and a portable gaming device and for that I love it. I can put it in the dock and play it on my TV. I can play it handheld which will be great for road trips or maybe just wanting to play anywhere. This was a brilliant move by Nintendo and it makes the Switch really stand on its own. Now what I‚Äôd say my favorite thing about the console is it‚Äôs simplicity. This device is made for one thing only and that is for playing video games. The console is both modern and old school at the same time. Would definitely recommend to anyone who really likes Nintendo and their games.

I bought the Switch a few months ago and now that I‚Äôve spent some time with it (more than I‚Äôd like to admit ^_^) I wanted to leave a review. The Switch has many pros over other consoles, it‚Äôs main pro being that it‚Äôs a portable console with games that previously are only found on PC or console. I am a PC gamer and my PC is an absolute beast with an 8700K & 2080 Ti BUT the reason I bought a Switch is because oftentimes I am out and about and can‚Äôt bring my big honkin‚Äô PC with me. Obviously I prefer my PC but it‚Äôs nice to be able to play games like Witcher 3 and then  when I have to go somewhere in the car or something I can seamlessly ‚ÄúSwitch‚Äù to the Switch and continue my game. There are some absolutely AMAZING games on the Switch: Zelda: Breath of the Wild, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe, Witcher 3, Splatoon, Super Smash Ultimate, etc., which are worth buying the Switch. This is especially true for people with kids as most of Nintendo‚Äôs big hits are kid friendly. You may not want your very young children to play violent games like Call of Duty or Battlefield 5 but they can definitely play a similar kind of game with Splatoon 2 only instead of shooting bullets to kill people they‚Äôre splattering paint all over each other. However the Switch also has its cons. Let‚Äôs start with Nintendo‚Äôs ‚ÄúE-Shop‚Äù. The E-shop sells games that are WAY overpriced. They charge $59.99 USD for games that have been out for years. The fact is you can buy physical copies of these games for less on Amazon AND you have the benefit of being able to resell the game later if you want too. Not so with digital games. Then there is the price. Yes the Switch is $299 which is cheaper than Microsoft and Sony‚Äôs consoles but when you factor in the cost of necessities that are almost required for optimal play (Pro Controller, SD card, Screen Protector) the cost adds up quickly. All in all though I do recommend the Nintendo Switch. It‚Äôs a great console for anyone who just wants to have a good time and it‚Äôs especially great for families or people with young kids who want to play games with them without worrying about violence, drug use, sexual situations, etc., that are in a lot of other games. 5/5 Stars

I got myself one of these, and my boyfriend one as well!  I absolutely love Nintendo products, and I haven't been disappointed by these consoles. I pretty much like the console. In portable mode, the ergonomics are quite good and the controls fall naturally under the fingers. The buttons are quite small and close together but you get used to it very quickly.  In Salon mode, nothing special, the console defends itself well, and the graphics are excellent for a console of this range.  A quick note on the parental control application which is also very practical and which lets you know how long players are using the console per day. Only one regret, however, the daily limit of playing time applies to the operation of the console and not to the time per player. Difficult to enforce equity between mhy childrens. Apart from that, excellent console.

Spent several days during the COVID-19 pandemic searching high and low for a Switch anywhere.  Most of what was available were 3rd party sellers charging $100 to even $200 over market value which is asinine.  Missed a couple stocks at Best Buys that sold out in seconds. Finally I just put on Netflix and had Amazon open and kept refreshing.  Missed a couple then finally had some used listings straight from Amazon for get this, $280! Order was delivered in two days.  Came in original box and had everything in packaging basically like it was new.  Screen had a protrctive film which was cool.  All controllers and adapters were nicely placed in plastic sleeves.  Everything was pretty much flawless.  The only thing is one joy con had barely any battery and the other was dead.  Not a huge deal got it charged in dock quickly. Everything was factory reset and when I started it up it was like it had never been turned on. DON'T BE SCARED TO BUY USED! AND DON'T LET THOSE PRICE GOUGERS TAKE YOUR MONEY! PATIENCE IS A VIRTUE! I was diligent for not even 48 hours and just kept checking and refreshing and eventually it paid off!

I bought this just to play Animal Crossing: New Horizons, and it didn't disappoint in the least! It's incredibly fun! One cool feature is that if you set up Parental Control using the free app, it will tell you how long you've played each day. Since I'm neither a parent nor do I need to be controlled, I disable restrictions and play-time limit so it doesn't actually interfere when I'm playing, but it is a bit sobering to see that yesterday I played for 6 hrs and 40 min. Also, if you set the play-time limit to 0 min everyday, the console will prompt you to disable Parental Control via a PIN. This could come in very handy if you have a sibling or roommate who likes to steal your Switch. I would also recommend getting a screen cover, either plastic or glass. I have a glass one that adheres like a second screen and haven't had any trouble yet, but then again I've only had it for 8 days and treat it very carefully. Overall, a great product, and worth every penny!

The Nintendo Switch has been extremely hyped up for me, so I finally gave in and bought one to play Animal Crossing and Ring Fit Adventure. PROS: - Nice console design - can play handheld, use the built-in stand to stand it on a table, or play it docked with a screen - Joy-con controllers are customizable - can get different colors. Interestingly, it also changes the value of the bundle, for example the Animal Crossing colors sell for much higher than the gray, which is higher than the neon colors. - Resolution is nice - Pretty easy to understand and use - Great battery life (make sure to get the 2020 v2) - Modern ports (USB-C) - Software is good and pretty well-designed - Great selection of games CONS: - Apparently keeping it docked can overheat the Switch, so some recommend purchasing an adapter that plugs in to the USB-C port instead of the dock it came with - Speed is a tad slow in opening games and gameplay - Joy-cons are quite non-ergonomic - mitigated a bit by the controller you can dock them in - Easily shows fingerprints/oils and scratches
LIKE SIZE, CONTROLLERS AND EVERYTHING ELSE ABOUT IT.  (This review was dictated by the 10 & 12 year old recipients.)

Upon looking for a Nintendo Switch, I discovered that it had been sold out in many different stores. I searched all over Walmart and kept on checking every day to see if I can at least snatch a good deal. Fortunately, I found a system available through a third-party vendor, I purchased it and afterward decided to research more about the company I had just bought the item from. The reviews from past online purchases stated upon things such as the company having terrible service, never receiving the purchased item, being unpleased with the experience and etc. I was surprised to have just bought a very expensive item from a company that has ratings so poor. I became worried but nonetheless waited until my package came. Once it did, I had nothing to complain about. I was lucky to not have any bad experiences with my order despite the bad reviews. The system came tightly secured in a box and included the system in a new condition. And, the box itself did not come with any signs of mishandlings or damage. The Nintendo system itself has not given me any problems and it running very well. Overall, I was happy ordering from Ant-online and would recommend it to anyone interested in purchasing a product from them.

It was purchased as a gift to a family member as a way to help with the stress of all that's going on and I couldn't be happier with my order! Thank you!

Kids love the device. All I see is a screen the size of a smart phone with potential for enormous in game addiction purchases. Controlling accounts appears to me to be set up in a way to capture those impulse purchases and discourage parents from blocking those charges. We've had all the games, accounts... this set up for Nintendo Switch Online was impossible to do without putting financial risk into the account. Nintendo have Family Accounts and Supervision. Upon inspection, those were just cardboard cutouts pretending to be real things. Work arounds galore when you read the fine print. Use at your own risk. Bank, Credit, Paypal linked accounts couldn't be added without entering that data into childs device, which puts it into a major security issue. Will use a cheapo disposable credit card and sacrifice ability to control childs content through a Family Account in order for them to be able to play.

The Switch Lite is cool but it feels a bit like a toy in your hands compared to the regular Switch, and feels a bit cheap. The Lite is perfect if you're buying for a child or if you're an adult who doesn't spend a ton of time gaming or travels a lot. Both the screen and the sound are good, so it's also perfect if you really don't feel the need to play on your TV and would rather spend less money than buying the regular Switch. I personally feel that Nintendo's games are perfect for handheld platforms so I find this product worth it and enjoy it. If you're more into gaming and know you're going to want to venture outside of Nintendo's platformer games with bigger games and action packed games, I wouldn't buy this if you're going to stick with one console.

My partner was very interested in getting a Nintendo switch after he saw me playing animal Crossing for quite some time. He wanted something a little bit more portable and didn‚Äôt need all the bells and whistle‚Äôs, so we decided to go with the switch light. It was simple and easy to set up, as the only thing that comes with in the box is the consul itself and the charging brick. We did opt to buy a larger micro SD card at some of the games he wanted to play with some of the largest on the Nintendo shop like Zelda breath of the wild and Skyrim. So far we have had no issues and he is loving playing his switch light every morning and evening, mostly on animal crossing for now. The battery life does seem to be decent as it actually outlasts my original Nintendo switch I got on launch day. The sound and audio is crisp and clear we have had no issues to report so far. I do recommend getting yourself a travel case and a glass screen protector from the get go however. I will say this. Do not fall for all the scams of people trying to sell the switch light for more than $199 retail value. Nintendo has been ramping up the production of the console and it is starting to be restocked everywhere slowly but surely. Don‚Äôt let these money hungry bandits take your hard earned money and charge you extra for a system just because of pandemic is keeping us in doors. Amazon is doing a good job of keeping it in stock here and there. Just be patient and it will be back.

My 10 year old son's review: I think that it is a great console! Has 2 Joy-Cons for good single and multiplayer action, has some great compatible games and is pretty strong with the Joy-Cons, which give it more protection, the Joy-Cons are also good for Bluetooth gaming, and can be used with other Nintendo Switches (and the new Nintendo Switch Lite). Has some good games, and great ports/remasters/expensive anime. Take your time to buy the original and be happy, there is a News area, A little album area, to store videos, and pictures, via using the Snapshot button on the Left Joy-Con, or via a specific area on the Micro SD Card, which can be inserted inside the back of the Nintendo Switch, and there is also options to have up to 8 users, and the console is region free, so you can make different region accounts, and get exclusive games, I recommend this to everybody, it can really make your day, except when its dead.

First: GET A SCREEN PROTECTOR PLEASE!!! If you're like me, you're on a tighter budget, so you grabbed this because it's cheaper and smaller. But get a normal switch. Trust me. Other than that 5 stars because it does what it says flawlessly. The games are fun, the handheld experience is great, it's not as heavy as a normal switch. Oh and get a screen protector because these things are insanely too easy to scratch up. I made that mistake and I'm paying for it. Figuratively and literally. To sum this all up, if you're looking for a cheap alternative to the switch and you don't mind losing the ability to dock it to a TV and replace joycons, and like the handheld experience, get this by all means. If you want to be able to play with a sibling or friends, save up that extra $100 because it's so much more worth it.

I've been wanting a switch for a long time, and finally managed to get my hands on one close to MSRP (at $307) during the pandemic. I only have one game on it so far, but to say I'm pleased and impressed so far is a bit of an understatement. It's nice to be able to play on my TV in the living room, and when someone else wants to play their own game or watch Netflix, I can just take the switch out of the dock and play in handheld mode, but stay in the same room and socialize. I like being able to bring the game into my room and not be forced to play it in the living room if I don't want to deal with all the noise. It's pleasant to hold, with just a bit of weight to it to feel sturdy. The Joycons are nice to the touch, although the sticks are a little too 'smooth' for my liking so I put some grips on. I haven't experienced any drift, yet, but it's only been a few days. They're very satisfying to hold, and even more satisfying to click into place on either the tablet or the included joy-con grip. I haven't tried the straps yet. The screen is lovely, and the speakers are front-facing so it seems louder than other handhelds. It IS a little frustrating to adjust the volume while I have it on the kickstand. The kickstand is a pain to pull out, and isn't sturdy in the slightest. Overall I'm very, very happy with it. I can't wait to get more games on it and play with friends.
Thankful to be able to snag one so we can stop arguing about who gets a turn playing it next in the house. When you have 4 people who all want to play and are all stuck at home...it's a nightmare.

Your browser does not support HTML5 video. The Nintendo Switch is great at well, switching, no matter if it's on the bus or in the living room, the Nintendo Switch is a great console for the family or the dedicated gamer. This version, the V2, is a big upgrade over the original Switch and has a very noticeable extended battery life compared to the original Switch, with newer joycons included and a brighter LCD screen. Love it, use it everyday!

Why? We got this model few weeks ago. The Joy-Con is already defective and this is a general issue with the Joy-Con on Switches. Just with the regular one, you do not need to replace the entire unit and you can just either get a new Joy-Con or fix it (very easy and cheap to do). Spoke with Nintendo Support, they need to get the Switch Lite for at least 3 weeks and no way to extend the warranty to cover these "guaranteed to fail" Joy-Con sooner or later. Besides that, with the $100 more you spend on the regular Switch, you get: 1) Docking Station to TV (Lite cannot do that) 2) Vibrating Joy-Con (Lite does not support this) 3) Ability to play some games the Lite cannot (including Legend of Zelda) as you need to have the controllers moving independently which the lite does not support. Save yourself frustration and limitations, avoid the Lite!

Got the console shipped to me on the 4th of Feb and I am already having issues with the right joystick. This isn't even a drift issue. When I press left, it registers as if it was fighting against me to push right. This started happening in less than two months. If you search youtube, there are plenty of videos of the issue. Some happening in less than a week. I could understand if I was rough with it, dropped it, stepped or sat on it. Although personally, I've treated it more gently than a friend's baby. I mean, I'm almost 40... I know how to take care of electronics and we've been locked down for half the time. It hasn't even left the house. I'm using a case, screen protector, the whole nine. I would be more understanding if Nintendo didn't try to push a product that they knew had defects. Look how long the fought again admitting the drift issue, let alone this. The Lite has the issue is built in to the console, so it's not like you can just send back the joycon and keep on playing games... Oh, and Nintendo isn't accepting warranty work at this time because of Covid-19. tl;dr + Awesome portable console w/ portability & amazing games on the go... Portable! - Bad build quality: Might be useless in weeks. No warranty repairs rn because Covid19. Be careful!
I love it

The photos don‚Äôt do it justice.  I grew up with Gameboy and super Mario games. I‚Äôm also PlayStation fan boy by heart and last time I had Nintendo was the original Wii which I still have. I decided to buy the Gray - Switch Lite since they announced Paper Mario (and rumored Super Mario Galaxy). Nintendo made a smart move by following the trend of remakes because I played these games from night until dawn in elementary school; I am 24 now. I‚Äôm so happy I bought the switch lite for its great value. This console is truly pushing the limits to current technology to its maximum. The screen is crystal clear while never compromising the vivid colors and games‚Äô unique styles exclusively on switch & cross platform games. During PS4, I became a huge indie game lover. The second my switch lite came, binge bought a bunch of great games under 9$ with real deals on gems of up to 90% off. My first switch game to buy and play is Planet Alpha (originally 20$ bought for 3.50$) and it‚Äôs perfect indie game that truly makes you understand the design of switch lite with comfort and ease; and again never comprising beauty exclusive switch game. The sense of ease and the light portability of the console that does not compromise the beauty of games full immerses you into a personal gaming experience that‚Äôs fun at any given moment. I also bought Overwatch on switch, which is also my go to on PS, to try and test my comfort level since I haven‚Äôt really played a handheld device in years. Overwatch is a great game to test the comfort on the switch lite because the game utilizes every button on the controller and in a fast paced. After a while it does feel a bit cramped but after adjusting the sensitivity you grow accustomed. OW surprised me so much and it is mind boggling to how they were able to compress the game onto this amazing console. Overall, I am satisfied and excited to spend years exploring the vast and diverse Nintendo library. This console is extremely worth it so far. No doubt Nintendo hit the nail on this console.

I want to start by getting the obvious out of the way. Scalpers = Trash, and I cannot believe with everything going on right now that Amazon is allowing them to sell at such inflated prices.  Wait for the official Amazon restocks because they charge MSRP, now onto the Switch. Love it. I cannot say that enough.  The console won't blow you away, but it will keep you entertained for hours. Whether you play in docked mode or handheld mode, they both work very well and looks very good on both screens.  The battery on this generation is much improved over the day 1 release.  The battery itself is the same size, but Nintendo put in a more efficient processor which extends the battery life. The game selection is wide and varied, if you like shooters, you can find them here. If you like platformers, look nowhere else, you have some of the greatest ever made. Not just this generation, but former generations in the Nintendo Eshop. The rundown is the Switch is a great console and worth the $299, just wait until Amazon gets it back in stock, stay far away from this worthless scalpers. Last note: Follow @FatKidAlerts on Twitter, he is always keeping up with Switch stock on Amazon, and that is how I finally got mine for MSRP.

This was my first hand held gaming device and I think it is a very unique, innovating what a portable console should be. I love the portability of it on the go and the ability to allow multiple players play at once. For $300 I think this is a solid gaming console that can be used to pour hundreds of hours into and still find games refreshing. The Nintendo game lineup also has the best exclusives out of the other competitors, from Mario to Zelda to Animal Crossing, there‚Äôs a game that suits anyone‚Äôs taste. Of course there are improvements to be made such as the joycons being small and sometimes uncomfortable in the even if you put it in together like a controller, it still doesn‚Äôt replace the feeling of a real full sized controller. In the future, I would just like Nintendo to make the portable screen 1080p with a 120hz refresh rate for an even better gaming experience. Of course this had to be 5 stars, it's Nintendo! This smaller, more lightweight version of the Switch definitely earns the title of "Lite", but dont let that fool you. Its every bit the power and capabilities of the big guy- just in a smaller, more portable, easier to carry and take with you body. I'd recommend the Switch Lite to casual gamers, those that dont really spend that much time on videogames and their vibe is more tailored to one-player games they catch up with every now and then while theyre in the subway on their way to work or at the kitchen waiting for dinner to finish cooking. The controllers dont detach like the original Switch does, but then again, if youre that much of a casual player, you dont need them too. You can still do multiplayer as long as its online, and in extreme scenarios it does recognize wireless controllers, so you can set it up as a mini screen instead, but that would be something more hardcore gamers would do, and for that, theres the oroginal Switch. This one is more private, more you-exclusive, your own little world just for you and no one else. That's the Switch Lite! And the colors? The original Switch wishes it could do that! Theres three fun colors to choose from (and black, well, more of like a really dark gray). I went with the yellow and havent regretted it since. People who see it love the color too. I hear its the color that most runs out of shelves because people love it so much, but I digress. The Switch Lite is a little beast! And every game for the Switch is just as playable and downloadable in it as it is for the original, and to top it off, its a full one hundred dollars less than the big guy! Itd say for a more personalized, maybe even casual gaming experience, you just cant beat the Nintendo Switch Lite. I love it!

Let's get down to buisness. Look: In my opinion it looks better than the original Switch, do not underestimate the gray, it is a great choice. The color contrast between the color of your choice and white is better than the joycon colors. Screen: For those nerds out there you will notice the higher pixel density, especially in games with more detail. Generally the screen is big enough for Fortnite, Pokemon Shield, and Zelda Breath of the Wild. I haven't played a game that felt unplayable yet. Controlls: Arguably it controls better than the original Switch, less clicky buttons and Nintendo's signature d-pad. Gyro controlls are still present, so aiming in Splatoon 2 and Zelda is the same as before. Feel: It feels far better than the original Switch for long play sessions, and it feels better in the hands. Battery life: Battery life is good, after a full charge I could play Minecraft at max simulation distance for 5 hours. But if you're going on the road yoh will need a battery bank. Notes: This is a handheld console only, you WILL NEVER be able to dock on a TV. There is also no rumble at all, although that'd be nice to have, you won't notice its abscence in-game. Lastly there is no IR sensor, and if you just asked yourself "what's and IR sensor" yoy won't care about it being gone. But because of the exclusion IR sensors Nintendo Labo and One Two Switch are unplayable. Advice: Don't buy One Two Switch, it will never be worth $60. Get a slim travel case, and a screen protector. If you are giving this to a child put AS MUCH PROTECTIVE CASING AS POSSIBLE.

The Switch Lite is a little smaller that the original switch, and due to that it is more comfortable to hold and play.  Since we got it a few months ago, it's been getting 2 to 4 hours of play a day (thank you Animal Crossing) and the battery only needs to be charged every 2nd or 3rd day. This is our 2nd Switch and we've 4 users on the 2 Switches.  We were disappointed to find that only one user can play a game that's downloaded onto a secondary Switch.  We initially downloaded Animal Crossing on the Switch Lite but only I could play the game and neither of my kids could.  So we ended up transferring the license to our "main" Switch, there all of us could play the downloaded version, and then put the physical game card in the Switch Lite (our secondary) and we all could play on that. So long story short, if this is your second or more Switch, buy the physical games rather than download them. Otherwise the Switch LIte runs just like a switch, only you can't display the output to a TV, it's only viewable on the unit itself.

I managed to snatch a retail price Switch away from scalpers somehow.  Which took about two months of attempts to pull off!  Anyways here is my honest assessment after watching repair videos. The Switch is an excellent console at an excellent value (As long as you can obtain one at MSRP).  However being what it is the Switch itself is fairly fragile.  If your child has the self control of Angry German Kid(tm) this would not be the best gift for them.  And if playing it in undocked mode understand by all that is holy that the Nintendo Switch is not a modern smartphone.  There is no water resistance built into the design.  Submerging the switch or even spilling something onto it will likely be the end of the console.  The docking port is another point of fragility.  It won't suffer being slammed into the dock well.  All of the weight of the unit is baring down on that port while docking so being gentle and sorta gingerly easing it down is advised.  The Joycons are also rather fragile.  Not flimsy but they won't tolerate mauling like let's say a PS1 controller could take. That being said I do not think the Switch is cheaply made at all despite these points.  The owner and operator just has to accept that they need to be gentle and they'll be fine.  And I don't mean you need to treat it like a china cup.  But this is NOT the kind of console for a roid rage neanderthal hopped up on Monster drinks and adrenaline.

Playing switch games is great, i bought 5 games with my system for variety. Turns out the most amazing feature i was not aware of before i started playing. The online subscription they offer for a measly 20 bucks a year offers a library of nes and snes games you can play at will. You can save state in them as well up to 4 save files for each game. You can ALSO reverse time when playing (it is a cheap feature but VERY cool still) Died in mario, just hold in two buttons, reverse the game like a dvr on tv show and bam, try that part again right where you just were!! i do not know if it is true but i read they have two more slots for future classic systems in their coding in the system. We have Nintendo 8bit, Super Nintendo but we could see Nintendo 64 or game cube in the future as well. All 5 games i picked up for it run great as well, no complaints except it was 150 dollars more than list price. Alas these are the times we live in.

At the time of purchase this listing was the only one I could find on Amazon for the actual list price of the Nintendo Switch Lite. Many others were massively price gouged. This was purchased for my partner as we both had started using our original full size Switch more and needed an additional console. The Lite gets right as a handheld system all the things the full size switch got wrong. It's much more light weight and far more comfortable to hold. It just feels right. Our original switch stays in docked mode 99% of the time. The screen size is perfect, I was nervous it would be too small but it's exactly where it needs to be. My only real issue with the screen is there's no way to tweak the settings other than brightness, but that's just nitpicking. The blue is a lovely color. Through the years we have had several Nintendo handheld systems in our household and I think the lite is my favorite so far.

In the picture it shows the Nintendo switch, the left blue controller and the right red controller are the same height. It's showing a Nintendo switch but the launch version. After I purchase it I thought I bought the wrong one because when I checked back on the picture and it shows a picture of the older version. The newer version shows the right red controller sliding up a little bit. When the Nintendo switch arrived at my house I was happy to see that it was the correct one showing the right red controller sliding up. The Nintendo switch that shows the right red controller sliding up has an extra 23 hours of portable battery life. Definitely worth the $500. Even if it is an extra $200. You can't get mad at someone being smart enough to stock up to make a profit. at least it's not some of these people that are trying to sell them for $1000. I would suggest purchasing Super Mario Odyssey as a game to go with it. It also comes with a 32 gig micro SD card. The Nintendo switch only allows you to use certain micro SD cards. (32 gig micro SD HC is the one that comes with it) I normally would have probably bought the wrong memory card otherwise. My nephew is going to love it. Fun fact this is all because of a kid named Nate who created this thing called bird bot. Anytime as soon as a Nintendo switch was manufactured it would immediately be sold to whoever previously put their credit card info in using bird bot. Thanks Nate... #Nates_a_piece_of_shit_that_just_cost_me_an_extra_$200_but_I_ain't_mad_at_ya(2-Pac voice)

Honestly, I‚Äôm in love. I haven‚Äôt really had a real current-gen console since college (about a decade). I bought an old Wii a few years back just for some party games (wasn‚Äôt a fan) and messed around with 3DS casually here and there but things changed when I got a Switch. It‚Äôs just absolutely brought me fully back into the gaming world. All of the Nintendo branded games are solid winners. Mario Odyssey was an amazing and fun game to test the waters with, Zelda BotW is the deepest and best game I‚Äôve ever played, Astral Chain is awesome fun, Animal Crossing is causal and super relaxing, and there are SO many amazing ports from other consoles that it almost feels pointless getting any other system. If you want more serious/intense action RPGs Skyrim is massive, Assassin‚Äôs Creed is a blast, Dragon‚Äôs Dogma is an underrated classic, and there are endless other options. Also the best for multiplayer games - Super Smash, Mario Kart, Overcooked are some of my wife and I‚Äôs favorites. My friend lent me a PS4, and while the games are bigger and with better graphics, nothing really beats being able to play your game on the big screen then grab it and play it on the couch or on the go. So convenient, so good. Nintendo really nailed it on this one. Everything about it feels pretty perfectly designed. Battery life is about 4-5ish hours, just need to get a good sized micro-sd for digital games and you‚Äôre good to go. Seriously one of the best purchases I‚Äôve made in a long time (Note - I bought my Switch a month before Covid hit so I got it for the standard price of about $300 - avoid the price gouged $400-500 price tags. You can find it cheaper elsewhere or just wait for the price to go back down)

It arrived safe and sound from the seller. I absolutely love it! I've been wanting to buy a Switch for a long time but debated on which one, the regular or LITE. Additionally, I decided to get my hands on separate joycons and a phone stand for the switch Lite which allows me to sit back on a chair and enjoy at a distance when I dont want to hold it. Overall, I'm glad to have made the purchase. Now I can finally play LOZ: BOTW at my own comfort and glee. Please note that if you plan to share the LITE in a family, it wouldn't be ideal as there is no docking option. This is ideal for  individuals who loves to travel around their own home or around other places. Sharing accounts isn't very ideal on this either,  so consider investing on a regular Switch instead or buy a physical  copy of the game if you wish to share.

I have an loaded opinion on this console that I want to express. The Switch is flawed. As an avid gamer who usually ends up buying all the consoles (except the xbox one) and loves the hardware behind these machines, the switch was super cool when I first heard about it and saw it. I got one not to long after release once they came back to my area. Though it took awhile to save up for any games as during that point in its life, everything was expensive on it and 3rd party devs hadn't moved to it yet. Also there were no media apps on it besides hulu which somehow is still a thing, surprising. But that isn't what I want to talk about, its more how the switch feels really damn cheap. I don't mean cheap as with the plastic shell either (but that is an issue, dislike the texture a lot, and it was also damaged by strong adhesives from dbrand before), but you get a wimpy TN panel for its main built in display, in an era where amoled and ips are very obtainable for device of this size (the original psvita was oled, so it could have been possible). As the resolution is at a solid 720p, which can help balance good enough quality on the go with actual game performance, I feel like they should have opted for a nicer quality screen to have better range of colors, would have created more vivid scenes using sharper and brighter colors. Instead they chose washed out TN panels which leave a lot to be desired when comparing it to any handheld screen semi modern hand held screen with exception of DS's which also chose awful screens. (and some might argue TN for faster response time, and to that, I highly disagree with improvements to other display types, and also for the type of audience the switch aims at) Next I want to talk about the Joycons, as they are lovely little controllers that snap onto the side of the console with a satisfying click. I actually wouldn't have minded them despite being kinda awful when using them on a big screen if they worked correctly, but three years in and these things are still built to fail. There is a major design flaw in them that eventually has the analogue stick wear our and start "drifting", making the controller effectively useless. If these were cheap, maybe I wouldn't care as much, but they are 80$ to replace. Sure you can contact nintendo customer support and they sometimes take care of you, but this is a hassle and shouldn't even be a problem. They could have just owned up to the mistake, and redesigned the controllers at this point. ( pro controller is actually a solid design, but its more expensive then both ps4 and xbox one controllers so I dislike recommending it. I believe its the amiibo sensor that does this and that's just bad). Lastly, I kinda wanna just complain about nintendo being nintendo. But before that I want to praise them for how far they did come up to this point. There is finally 3rd party content being pushed on the Switch and thats awesome. It seems like they did listen a bit and made it much easier to get games on the Switch. Ok now onto the bad. The Switch has no utility, and I get that its a gaming console, but still its surprsing that the most mobile and potentially flexible console lacks basic OS features that things like the ps4, psvita, and even 3DS were capable of doing such as, have a variety of streaming services, a basic web browser, and customizing the layout of your home screen/having fun backgrounds. There is no personality to the switch despite it being one of the most unique consoles I have ever seen, which is quite baffling to me. Despite the console featuring bluetooth for its joycons and pro controller, you cant connect bluetooth headphones to it without a 3rd party adapter, which is a little baffling for an on the go console. The UI looks pretty ugly when put onto a big screen, just a personal gripe of mine, I really don't like it. Lastly, the game cartridges are a letdown. The reason games usually feel more expensive on the switch is because they more often then not are. This is due to the game cartridges costing more to make than blu-ray media for the other consoles. Nintendo also didn't want a disparity of cost between physical media and digital media, so if you launch a game both ways, you need to have the price be the same, which creates higher costing digital games on the switch store vs any other platform. The cost of the cartridge also varies depending on size of the game, so larger games will suffer more to this than smaller ones. That's my loaded opinion which turned more into a typed rant on the switch. Its still a pretty ok console that provides a ton of unique experiences that you can't get on any other platform. As a sole console I don't think I would recommend this unless you fully know what you are getting into, but as a side device to play exclusives its not bad. Hopefully they will release new hardware and software updates to fix many of the gripes I rambled on about.

I've owned Nintendo products my whole life. I was 2 when the NES released and had my first one when I was 6. I love Nintendo consoles and games. I love that I can leave my kids to play with them and not worry about inappropriate content. We bought our first switch just over a year ago. We loved everything about it from the mobility to the graphics. Mario kart became an instant family tradition. Unfortunately, the charging port went out, just after warranty. One thing we've come to love from Nintendo is the durability. I have an original NES that still works. We have a WII that's 15 years old and still going strong. To only get a year out of a $400 console is unacceptable.  I've been told that it likely can't be repaired, as the motherboard is so thin it doesn't accept new soldering without blowing through it. I am very pleased with the Switch and am very happy with it. I have played on it for a week so far and everything is working fine and dandy, as it should. One gripe is that the storage capacity is small so only a few games can be played at a time, but with a micro SD card, possibilities are endless. I ordered one of those, and expect it soon so I can expand my downloaded game collection. I've enjoyed the Switch so much I'm getting some additional joycons and a grip and a charging station. Nintendo really seems to be cheaping out on their consoles now. Not even two months into my ownership of my brand new Switch Lite, and the left joy stick is already going out (the calibration test confirmed my suspicions). Normally, you could just chalk this up to bad luck, a one in a million chance... at least, you would if this wasn't the second consecutive time you've received a lemon console. This same exact issue plagued my new 2DS XL when I bought it 3 years ago, and after that nightmare of a repair I can't believe this happened again. Sent that in for repair and it came back with a loose dust cover flap, along with greasy fingerprints all over both screens! As someone who takes great care of their consoles, I was horrified. With this knowledge comes extreme disappointment that Amazon won't replace my system, as I am very reluctant to send it in to Nintendo's chop shop. The possibility that I could just be sent a refurbished console kills me even more. I bought a NEW console for a reason, why would I want to receive in return something that is anything less? Aside from my obviously bum joy stick, the functionality and appearance of my Switch is otherwise pristine. I mean, I wipe this thing down with my microfiber cloth every time after I turn it off, then promptly put it back in it's case. Considering also all the features I lost, plus a worse battery than the new model Switch, I genuinely feel like I got screwed. Getting $100 off ain't lookin' so good all of a sudden. I would give a lower rating, but the quality of the games I have counter balance it a little. Nintendo loses yet another point in my book.

I understand wanting to make sure the money is there before sending the item, but just drop the pending charge right away. This is a seller issue, and not my bank. It usually takes about 24 hours for a pending charge to drop from most places. BEWARE!!!! You will be charged double until they decide to drop the pending charge.

I bought this to play animal crossing with my girlfriend and maybe a few other titles for myself if it worked out that way. After a few months with this device my conclusions are this: Animal crossing was fun. There are plenty of games for this machine, but it is underpowered compared to a regular switch. Demos I have downloaded such as resident evil have had frame rates that look to be 15 or 20, stuttery and just bad. The Nintendo Online service, which I needed to play the game with my girlfriend and browse their online store, costs you a monthly fee and seems to have literally no curation or thought put into it, while also having the most expensive prices I have seen and the worst sales. Id love to try out more titles but next to nothing good ever goes on sale, and from what I have researched this is normal Nintendo. The Zelda game is supposed to be good, but it is still $60 and never goes on sale yet it‚Äôs almost 4 years old.  Come on. This is a fun system, just beware of its limitations and costs.

What is there not to like? I've had the Xbox 1 and the PS4 since they came out but put off on buying the Switch when it came out. I cannot play first person shooter games, it literally makes me sick. I was never a huge video game player. Mainly because I could only go a few hours stairing at a big TV or having my laptop on my lap. I could never really get comfortable. Not to mention the money it costs to have a laptop that is powerful enough to play the most popular games. Having to download games is also a hassle because my internet is limited. So an option where I can just buy the physical versions of games and pop them in? It sounds 'stone age' to most, but is what has been amazing for me. I now have something to do when I am feeling isolated and lonely. The absolute boredom and emotional pain that has been the last eight months of my life. I've found something that makes things easier to cope with. Keeps me connected to several of my friends, gives me and them something to do, something to do together. The lite is perfect for me because I am the only person in my household interested in playing games and it's perfect for my small hands. I've had nothing but fun and happiness from this little but powerful machine.

First things first I got my Switch from Mums Collectibles & Stuff so this will mostly be a review of them as I've already owned a Switch and knew what to expect from the system. What most people don't realize is that consoles are in high demand this year (2020) and we all know the reason so I can't fault a company for increasing the price on item due to high demand and low stock of said item. That being said Mums Collectibles & Stuff is by far the cheapest I have seen a new switch go for on amazon, ebay or a number of other websites. On top of all of this one I bought the item from them they had it ready and shipped the next day as I did buy it rather late at night. With an estimated arrival time of 2 weeks I actually received it a week early which I give my thanks to UPS. When I opened the package I found they took the time to make sure that the switch was secure and safe with two layers of massive bubble wrap which was just extra enjoyment. All in all they are the cheapest, quickest and most reliable source to get a switch right now.

Similar to other Nintendo systems, innovation is always attached to their new ideas. The joy cons are similar to the wii remotes, albeit not as precise for some games where they were used for shooting type games, the joy cons are incredible for multiplayer. I honestly prefer using one joycon whenever I can when playing games, it's really nifty being able to play two player automatically with a friend or family member without having to pay for an expensive controller, or a cheaper built one. Nintendo Apps are so-so at the moment, it would be great to have streaming apps such as Netflix for streaming, but other apps such as Youtube have worked well streaming but I do not like the interface for searching for videos. When playing online, after paying for a year subscription, was not as bad as the days of the Nintendo Wii, but it could be better. Wifi play has always been a struggle for companies and consumers that I don't expect to go away with any patch made by Nintendo. Buying the year subscription also includes many nes/snes games you can play with the joy cons in single/multiplayer. My roommate got rehooked playing super mario world and it was a blast seeing someone who says they "hate games with bad graphics". Overall, if you're looking for a system for on the go or for a house hold device, the Nintendo Switch is a excellent system with a good range of games to play on. My young nephew and kid siblings are a fan of it; and same for me and several of my friends who are in our early 20s.
This is the best thing ever. The only complaint I have is that the battery goes down really fast but otherwise i would totally recommend this to anyone that wants to get a gaming device.

I‚Äôve had my Switch for about a year now and I can say it‚Äôs a very fun console. It‚Äôs no where near as powerful as the PS4 or Xbox but the fact that I can take my games on a road trip or play it at home is pretty awesome and convenient for gamers. The Joy-Cons do get loose however over time and will slide off without having to press the release button so I would recommend getting a grip or a case like the picture shown above. Another thing I wan to mention is the joy con drift, which can get really annoying at times. Having to calibrate them in the settings menu every other minute can be really annoying and for others, ruin the experience. I usually use a pro controller while playing on docked mode and I don‚Äôt run into any issues but the problem persists when I‚Äôm playing on table top or handheld. Besides the minor inconvenience here and there, I think the Nintendo Switch is great, especially with third party games like Skyrim or the Witcher 3 being ported over to the Switch. It‚Äôs a great little console.

Not a fan of the typical Nintendo styled games, but ever since they started putting out real titles like Witcher, Skyrim, bioshock. I‚Äôm sold and not bad graphics either I mean to be expected but not as bad as I thought.

Had it for almost a week and enjoying it. A few hiccups here and there but nothing major. Bought some accessories for it too. Just wish software can continue to download without stopping in the process while in screen lock. Also, wish it had built in bluetooth. It‚Äôs 2020 and I was quite shocked to learn that none of the switches (regular and lite) have built in bluetooth, so I will have to buy a bluetooth adapter for it. I am not a fan of the built in speakers. Some games allow the full range of volume, while some make the system sound very low which is the reason I want bluetooth to use my JBL speaker for a better experience. It‚Äôs a handheld, which I understand, so I am not too bothered by it. Overall, I still prefer over the regular because I wanted a handheld for personal experience rather than share with others. It‚Äôs a cute color.

Quick shipping, well packed. The console is easy to setup and use and fun to play. Games are pricey, but I expected that. There are some "bargain" games available, so you could get hours of gaming pretty cheap if you wanted, but if you want to play the big name games (Kart, Party, Smash Bros, Animal Crossing, Zelda, etc.), you gotta shell out $60 a game. What really ticked me off was the $5 a month charge to play online. I bought the console for playing with my family remotely, since, thanks to COVID, we don't see each other often, so I pretty much had to pay the reoccurring charge for this service. Considering the price of the console, then the games, then extra controllers, etc etc this extra charge is ridiculous. After buying just two games, I'm $420 into this console already, now I have to pay $60 a year? I knocked off a star for that.

The Nintendo Switch Lite offers handheld only play. Which is fine. The color of the Lite is cosmetic only with many different case and skin options. I was able to play a game on the Lite as I play on my console and the first thing I noticed was graphic issues. Distant artifacts (moving objects, other players, static objects) tend to be more pixelated. The farther away they were the more pixelated they were. Some I couldn‚Äôt even recognize, even though I‚Äôm extremely familiar with the game. A simple 15 minute game play reduced the battery from 100% to 83% with the game mentioned earlier. Battery life varies from game to game. The device got warm while playing but was noticeably warmer while charging, in sleep mode. Thankfully there is a setting to power the device completely off to save battery instead of keeping it in sleep mode. The device felt sluggish trying to play said game. Not sure if the game was taxing the system as there is a lot going on and needs to be connected to WiFi. Has many Nintendo classic games for sale of course, or you can buy new games for $60. Which the price of them doesn‚Äôt fall for almost a year. The screen is a touchscreen. Overall I would give the Nintendo Switch Lite a generous 4/5 stars. But I‚Äôm reality it‚Äôs a 3/5 star device due to no backward compatibility with prior system games, high cost of games long after they‚Äôve came out, very limited free games section, weak battery life and as I said before a weak graphics chip. The Lite should have cost $150, with the regular switch costing $250. If you see the Lite being sold for more than $199 then your being scammed. Buy from someone else or someplace else. The regular Switch is being sold for $299. Again higher prices means your being scammed. Regardless of the color of the device or controllers.

First, I'm going to start by saying there are a ton of things to love about the Nintendo Switch. The problem I have has more to do with the service provided by Nintendo. A company is not only judged by what they can produce but how they stand behind their products. I had a game card that started failing shortly after 90 days and so I contacted the Nintendo technical support. I was told the repair would be $30 and an additional $10 in shipping. I was also told it would take 5 weeks time for the repair. Now this is where I need to be pretty blunt. Asking me to pay $40 to repair a game card when the original game was only $49.95 is an absolute rip off and not a sound investment. Furthermore, you don't repair these kinds of game cartridges. Inside the card is usually a single IC chip soldered to a board so the chip can be read by the card reader. Even Intel does not "repair" their CPUs or other IC chips so it is easy for me to say Nintendo does not either. If anything, the unit will be replaced, which does not take 5 weeks. At this point, what adds insult to injury is the same game is available on the Nintendo eShop for $59.95. The digital download version of the game does not suffer the same issues with losing your game due to faulty cartridges. The use of digital copies has been huge for movies, and many of them give it to you for free. Nintendo has you pay more and it is a separate purchase as if you did not have the game to begin with. My issue here is I do not have any mechanism to backup my games to protect them without using the same tools used by bootleggers. I should not have to resort to such a tactic and Nintendo should do more to support my investment. Taking this one step further, I have issue with the fact Nintendo does not put any warranty information on the outside packaging so a buyer can be aware before making the decision to purchase their products. Even on Amazon, you are linked to another page and then referred to the manufacturer with no direct link. As a game buyer, whether retail or online, products are not very readily available for inspection. In standard brick-and-mortar stores, you have to get a sales assistant to review the package. Online, you are limited to what the retailer has decided to make available. In any case, I should not find out the details when I am most in need. So if you are buying into this game console ecosystem, there is more to the decision than how exciting their games are because the service is nothing but exciting and are at best reluctant to stand behind their products. I have given this product a single star because my decision to purchase the Nintendo Switch has been met with nothing more than being on my own after spending a lot of money. Excited gamers means lots of sales. Gamers who feel they have been taken advantage of simply have options with other consoles. I think you can guess which category I'm in and I hope you think twice about the company behind this one.

I'm suppose to love the Switch, but I don't.  I think it's a bad deal overall. 1) Nintendo Online doesn't offer much compared to the Wii virtual console days.  There's no Metroid games from the GC/Wii/Advance era.  Nearly all the games for the switch look like something from the 90's when flash games were popular. But the games are priced as if they're made out of gold. 2) The frame rate on this console is poor. Yeah, some games reach a respectable 30fps, but I'd say most games fall below that. 3) The dock is very woobly, it doesn't lock in, and it's very easy to scratch up the screen. 4) There is no wired connection out of the box.  Why should I have to buy an adapter for that?  If you play online seriously, you use a wired connection. 5) Here's what really bugs me.  There's no web browser on this thing.  No web browser for a mobile device? Are you kidding me?  This also leads to bizarre consequences.  Since there's no reviews on the Nintendo store, you're forced to go to third party sites for reviews... but you can't, because there's no web browser.  LMAO! And I had to create my nintendo account on a PC!  ROFL! Conclusion: I'll stick with the PC, Xbox and Playstation.  If these issues ever get resolved, I'll reconsider.  It's an interesting design, but it's all hype - little value.  $300 is way overboard for this gimmicky soy toy.
